Thanks for taking my question. Could you give some color on your OPEB obligations, post the UAW and Canadian VEBA? Is there going to be a material obligation, or is that obligation on that currently?

Well, let me talk about it. And then I can't answer your question in terms of providing the quantification because we need to go through re-measurement. But, if you think about OPEB more broadly, it is addressed. I think about the UAW, basically, we don't have any ongoing to obligations post 1-1. We delivered the note. We delivered the preferred and they have the shares. So I mean, importantly the UAW obligation is, at that point, defeased really. The IUE, and the steelworkers and a number of the other unions, we've negotiated agreements with them, which basically provide similar treatment to our salaried workforce.

Our salary workforce capped, and not only capped pre-65, but post-65. Were out of the business. And then, finally, on life insurance, we've also implemented a number of changes, which will result in a fixed amount of OPEB and a substantially lower amount of OPEB. All that has got to get put through the system, but I think we believe we have addressed OPEB in the U.S. I think we've addressed OPEB in Canada in a permanent way.

And in terms of quantifying it, as Ray talked about when he went to the deck, we haven't put the note in the preferred on the books yet, because we still have the OPEB on the books. So we need to go through the processes when we finish press start of basically removing the OPEB obligations and putting the debt and the preferred back on the books. When we have that, we'll obviously be happy to share that with you. We just haven't done that yet.
So I mean from the North America side, we should still see both of these – salary OPEB will still be there, and there will be life insurance, and then there is no change to the international OPEB?

Well, international is Canada. We don't really have material OPEB outside of North America. We do have material pension outside of North America . For example, Germany, UK – Germany is actually the biggest one, but we don't anticipate any changes in those liabilities going forward. They're still with us.

Okay. My second question, you seem to highlight the numbers for new GM and sort of exclude the first 10 days of old GM, but since the old GM numbers are taking up special items, at least when you look at EBIT perspective, I mean shouldn't we not just be looking at the combined number for those first 10 days as sort of a metric of how you're doing, or is that not the correct way to look at it?

Well. they're not comparable and I would be remiss if I didn't remind you that they're not comparable. I mean, I think you can make your own judgment. We've supplied the data. But in some cases, for example, when we go through fresh-start accounting, those numbers are going to fundamentally change. So, I mean, I can't give you any advice in that regard. But Ray talked about for example cash payments and supplier payment. It is relevant to mention that as you look at, for example, cash flow in the quarter. But I wouldn't – it wouldn't be fair to provide you with advice and suggest you add those two cases, because in a number of cases, they're not comparable.

And you actually just mentioned cash flow. I think you said that working capital should be a negative in Q4. Why should that be? I mean, this quarter, part of the benefit was the production increase and you're guiding through a production increase again in – quarter-over-quarter at least in Q4. Is there some – why wouldn't we see another working capital benefit?

No, actually, as we look at it, I think that what we won't – we won't have the same extent of the buildup of 8.2 billion. We're also going to have this $2 billion one-time adjustment from going to net 47 from MNS2, which will go the other way. It's a one-time item. Those would be the two factors I would point to. But I wouldn't say that we will have a working capital burn per se. I do think we're going to have this two billion effect, which we're going to deal with, but what we won't necessarily have is the 8.2 billion buildup.

Okay. And just one last one, when you look at the structural cost, at least the rate of it for the new GM versus what you had year-to-date, it actually doesn't seem to be a huge decrease. Only looks like $1 billion if you were to annualize the run rate. I mean, has there not been – I mean, what has structurally changed pre and post bankruptcy when you look at new and old GM, what sort of – in terms of head count, what are the main factors that change it or is it really not much change on the structural front?
Collin, what numbers are you referring to?
I guess I'm looking at the 9 billion this quarter and then – I guess on your press release.
I mean, if you look at chart 21.
Yeah.

Again, these don't have fresh-star accounting, but if you look at it relative to the '08 period, I mean, it's a pretty significant decline, which does reflect the reductions in manpower, both salaried and hourly, engineering, capacity reductions in the plants. We're well on track to achieving our goals on structural costs.

I guess what I was trying to get at is, I'm looking at the run rate of the 22 versus the 9.1. And I think if you were to put it on a data basis – maybe that's not fair, but they seem fairly similar. So were there any additional actions since you filed for bankruptcy that would have taken the cost you were running at or the changes you had done before bankruptcy even further below is that 9-1, is there more opportunity there?

Well, I think we would see further reductions as we get into 2010 as we finalize our actions. But I think, my take away from this is that we were – we have been achieving the goals. We will execute the rest of our operating plan and hit our structural cost numbers, again. Ray is right. We need to apply fresh-start accounting, which will apply amortization expense to it, but I'll call it pre fresh-start accounting. We feel like we're on path to achieve our structural cost goals. It's always hard with this nine-day period. But if you divide 22 by two, you get 11; and it's – and obviously, you've got an 80-day period, which is 9-1. So I mean, I do think we're on the right glide path.
Okay. All right. Thanks for taking my question.
You're welcome.
That does conclude the question-and-answer session. At this time, I'll turn the call back to our speakers.
Okay. Operator, thank you very much and thanks everyone for joining us this morning. Have a great day.
Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude the conference call for today. We thank you for your participation. And ask that you please disconnect your line.
